resources.string: The root certificate is not signed by Google.
The attestation is not implemented by secure hardware, it can be easily modified.

Version:
The version of the key attestation feature.

Version:
The version of the Keymaster hardware abstraction layer (HAL). Use 0 to represent version 0.2 or 0.3, 1 to represent version 1.0, and 2 to represent version 2.0.

Security level:
The security of the implementation.

  • Software
    Implemented by the Android system. This is much less secure than the other two levels and should only in older devices.
  • TrustedEnvironment
    Implemented in secure hardware, such as a TEE (Trusted Execution Environment).
  • StrongBox
    Implemented in a dedicated hardware security module. Devices initially shipped with Android 9 or higher could have the module installed.

The purpose of the challenge value is to enable relying parties to verify that the key was created in response to a specific request.

In production environment, the challenge value should be randomly generated every time.
This value identifies the deviceâ€”but only for a limited period of time. It is computed and is only used by system apps. In all other apps, uniqueId is empty.
This item is enforced by the Android system, not by the device\'s TEE.
This item is enforced by the device\'s TEE.

This data structure contains the key pair\'s properties themselves, as defined in the Keymaster hardware abstraction layer (HAL).

App developers can compare these values to the device\'s current state or to a set of expected values to verify that a key pair is still valid for use.
Specifies the set of purposes for which the key may be used.
Specifies the cryptographic algorithm with which the key is used.
Specifies the size, in bits, of the key, measuring in the normal way for the key\'s algorithm.
Specifies the digest algorithms that may be used with the key to perform signing and verification operations.
Specifies the padding modes that may be used with the key. This tag is relevant to RSA and AES keys.
